origination.corpname: University of Michigan. Matthaei Botanical Gardens.

did.unittitle: Matthaei Botanical Gardens (University of Michigan) records 1905-2007 1965-2004
did.abstract: Established in 1897, the Matthaei Botanical Gardens, with its mission to study and disseminate knowledge of plants as they exist in nature, serves as an educational resource for the university and local community. In 2004 the Botanical Gardens and Nichols Arboretum were joined as a single administrative unit. The records document the Gardens' various organizational, research, and community service activities.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group was transferred by the Matthaei Botanical Gardens (Donor No. 6701) in several accessions, the latest in 2013. 6701

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are expected.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Matthaei Botanical Gardens (University of Michigan) records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: At the time of the founding of the University of Michigan in 1817, administrators provided for the establishment of a "Botanic Garden." However, it was not until 1897 that the gardens were established. At that time, they served as an adjunct of the Department of Botany and the College of Pharmacy, located on the central campus. When this location proved to be inadequate, professors Frederick C. Newcombe and Volney M. Spaulding attempted to obtain a new site.

In 1906, Professor Newcombe successfully secured twenty-seven acres of land, located between Geddes Avenue and the Huron River, from Dr. and Mrs. Walter H. Nichols. In order to enlarge this property, George P. Burns, later the first director of the gardens, acquired twenty-five acres of adjoining property from the city of Ann Arbor and another thirty acres from the Detroit Edison Company.

The new "Botanical Gardens and Arboretum" existed under the jurisdiction of the Department of Botany, of which Director Burns was a staff member. Burns' appointment as director began in 1907 and ended in 1910, at which time he left Ann Arbor to head the Department of Botany at the University of Vermont. After several acting directors, Henry Allan Gleason became director and served from 1915 to 1919.

Dissatisfaction with the Geddes area site arose around 1913, because the land was not flat enough for experimental gardens. President Hutchins reorganized the administration of the gardens by creating a "committee of management," who purchased an additional twenty acres of land in 1914, near Packard Road beyond the city limits. This site later became known as the "Iroquois Site." The Department of Botany and College of Pharmacy utilized this site, while the Departments of Landscape Design and Forestry continued their use of the Geddes site. The latter eventually became the Nichols Arboretum.

Harley Henry Bartlett succeeded Gleason in 1919, and soon President Hutchins once again reorganized the administration of the gardens. The Botanical Gardens became an autonomous department in the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts. Although the Department of Botany was to have no control over gardens policies or budgets, the gardens directorship was to be filled by a faculty member from the department.

The "Iroquois Site" remained the location of the Botanical Gardens through Bartlett's tenure as director, which ended in 1955. Bartlett was succeeded by A. Geoffrey Norman. As the rapidly developing city of Ann Arbor encroached on the site, it became an unsuitable location for the gardens. To remedy the situation in 1957, Mr. and Mrs. Fredrick C. Matthaei gave approximately 250 acres of land near Dixboro, to which the university added an additional 100 acres. The dedication took place on June 14, 1962, and in 1969 the property was renamed the Matthaei Botanical Gardens in honor of the donors.

After the move, several important facilities, such as a conservatory, greenhouses and classrooms, were built through three-phased construction from 1959 to 1965. With the increase in facilities and the expanded availability of natural areas, research and teaching opportunities at the Gardens considerably expanded.

Dr. Warren H. Wagner, Jr. succeeded Dr. Norman as director in 1966, and Professor Erich E. Steiner succeeded Dr. Wagner in 1971. In 1974, during Steiner's tenure, the Gardens' membership program, "Friends of the Matthaei Botanical Gardens," was established. This group, comprised of Ann Arbor area residents, conducts annual fund drives for the gardens. Steiner resigned in 1977 and was replaced by Professor William S. Benninghoff, who had been very active in the development of the Dixboro site. He was later succeeded by Catherine Bach (1985-1987); Anton Reznicek (1987-1989); Erich Steiner (1971-1977, 1989-1991); William S. Benninghoff (1977-1986); Catherine Bach as Acting Director (1986-1987); Anton A. Reznicek (1987-1989); Patricia Hopkinson as Acting Director (1991-1994); James A. Teeri (1994-2002); and Brian J. Klatt as Interim Director (2002-2004).

The Gardens typically have over 30 research projects conducted each year by University of Michigan and non-University of Michigan researchers. In addition, the Gardens provides plant material for U-M courses and is the site for regular classes or field trips for approximately 20 classes from U-M and six other colleges and universities. In addition to research, thousands of visitors come to the Conservatory and grounds each year to participate in adult education courses, volunteer activities, and special events or just to visit the grounds. Two auxiliary organizations that are vital to the success of these programs are the Friends of the Matthaei Botanical Gardens, founded in 1974, and the Docents, who were formally organized in 1982.

In 2003, the associate provost Janet Weiss explored the possibility of combining the Botanical Gardens and the Arboretum. In 2004 the two units were united as a single independent unit of the University of Michigan. In 2007, the Botanical Gardens celebrated its 100 year anniversary. A separate records group for Nichols Arboretum is available at the Bentley Historical Library.
Further information can be found in the Matthaei Botanical Gardens and Nichols Arboretum collection, which covers the records of the units after they combined.

scopecontent.p: The Matthaei Botanical Gardens records comprise 21 feet of materials spanning the years 1905 to 2007. The records document the Gardens' various organizational and community service activities ranging from administration work to special events for the public. The records have been divided into 11 series: Administrative, Correspondence, Topical, Photographs and Scrapbooks (except for Friends and Docents), Friends of Matthaei Botanical Gardens, Docents, Events, Plans, Projects, Research, and Topical Files. Unfortunately, due to multiple accessions and different processors, these series are not exclusive and researchers are advised to examine the entire finding aid carefully.

scopecontent.p: The Administrative series, 1910-2001 (5 linear feet), is arranged alphabetically and primarily consists of reports and memoranda. The background folder contains informative documents that explain the purpose, organization, and history of the Botanical Gardens. Annual reports and Committees are the largest subseries. The annual reports are yearly accounts of collection development and research projects at the gardens. The Committees subseries contains incomplete records of four committees: Ad Hoc Study, Budget Review, Executive, and Literature, Science, and the Arts Program Evaluation. The Executive Committee records are the most comprehensive, consisting of minutes, reports, and memoranda from the years 1913-1919 and 1980-1986. Though less comprehensive, the other committee records provide insight into the gardens' administration at specific points in time. Also included in the Administrative series are materials on budget, grants, planning and scheduling including the master plan for the years 1980-1985. Docent guides and documents concerning conservatory renovation are also included. The series continues in Box 11.

odd.p: (2 rolls microfilm, security copy, stored separately [Cold Room 13-6 BD-Bj Bimu C262])

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series, 1911-1987 (3 linear feet), is arranged into two subseries: General and Topical. The General subseries is arranged first by year and then alphabetically within each year. The Topical subseries is arranged alphabetically. The correspondence are comprised of both incoming and outgoing letters, the latter written by the director and various employees of the gardens. The letters are quite informative and are an important source for studying the evolution and growth of the gardens and its relationship to other major botanical gardens around the country. The continuation of this series, beginning in Box 12, is organized alphabetically.

R.S. Barnwell Memorial Garden, Shreveport, LA 1972
Dean of Literature, Science and the Arts 1981-1983

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files series, 1907-2003 (3.3 linear feet), is arranged alphabetically. The researcher interested in architecture will find blueprints of buildings and grounds from the years 1914-1920 and 1959-1965. Topics represented in this series include research, education and employment, garden collections and inventory, public programs, and special events. There is material concerning Fleming Creek, which runs through the present day site of the Matthaei Botanical Gardens and is a tributary of the Huron River. These include memoranda, a summary of creek fauna, and information and reports from the Huron River Watershed Council concerning the roadway design of highway M-14 and its effects on the creek. The newspaper clippings offer information on the operation of the gardens from 1950 to 1972. Researchers interested in the gardens' history will find information on the adoption of the Dixboro Site. The series continues in Box 17.

odd.p: (Address given by Patricia Hopkinson upon his retirement)

Photographs and Scrapbooks (except Friends and Docents)

scopecontent.p: The Photographs and Scrapbooks (except for Friends and Docents) series (1.5 linear feet) consists of photographs, negatives, matted photographs, and three scrapbooks containing photographs and newspaper clippings. The images represent grounds, buildings, and individuals. Of particular interest are photographs documenting daily operation and staff members at work, and those documenting special events such as the Auxiliary Pot Luck in 1967, and the A.G. Norman Memorial in 1987. Photographs and scrapbooks about either the Friends or Docents of Matthaei Botanical Gardens are listed under those groups' series. The series continues in Box 15.

did.unittitle: Benninghoff, Anne and Collins, William W. IV
"Joy of Life" Exhibition of Artwork by Hanne Eske Dyva 1998
LaRue, Jane, Dedication of Memorial Sundial 1986
Norman, A.G. and Kleinschmidt, Walter F. 1966

scopecontent.p: The Friends of Matthaei Botanical Gardens series, 1974-2002 (1.8 linear feet) is organized into two subseries: Administration and Organizational History. The Administration subseries consists of documents generated during the administrative and routine functions of the organization, such as agendas, minutes and correspondence. The Organizational History subseries comprises documents created or saved by the organization because they document the group's history. Of particular note are the organizational materials relating to the development of the Friends and scrapbooks of newspaper clippings about the Friends. This series continues in Box 14.

did.unittitle: Guidelines for Board Members of Friends 1999

scopecontent.p: The Docents series, 1983-1997 (0.5 linear feet) documents the organization that was created in 1982 to train, manage and support docents at the gardens. The series includes mainly administrative documents generated by the organization, as well as a limited number of documents related to the history of the organization. Of particular note are a group of photographs that identify by name docents pictured performing their duties at the gardens.

The Events series, 1987-2007 (0.4 linear feet) contains information related to the various programs sponsored by the Botanical Gardens. Of particular note is the information on the Ann Arbor Flower and Garden Show which comprises most of the series. Other events, such as Matthaei by Moonlight and the Gateway Garden Dedication, are also included in this series.

did.unittitle: Admission Booth/Reciprocal Arboreta, Gardens, and Conservatories 1993

scopecontent.p: The Plans series, 1923-2004 (2 linear feet) contains specific information relating to various parts of the Gardens. These site plans cover the purchase and development of the Dixboro Site, the development of Fleming Creek, and other plans revolving around renovations pertaining to specific properties owned by the Gardens. These plans also cover the development of specific garden plots and themed plant beds located in the Gardens, such as the Labyrinth Garden and the Gateway Garden.

did.unittitle: Horner -- McLaughlin Woods Checklist of Woody Plants
Horner's Woods and Michigan Botany Club 1964-1965
Plants at Gardens, Horner, and McLaughlin Woods 1965-1971
Wildflowers of the Great Lakes Region 2000
Wildflowers of the Southern Great Lakes 1997

scopecontent.p: The Projects series, 1961-2002 (0.5 linear feet) contains information on broader construction projects compared to the Plans series. This includes the construction of the Friends Pavilion, the renovation of the inside of the conservatory, the plans for repairing the damage done to the gardens by storms, and the creation of the Hot Line for Poisonous Plants.

The Research series, 1959-2004 (0.7 linear feet) contains information on various research projects done at the Botanical Gardens. Included is information from various biology and botany classes that researched the gardens as well as personal research projects done by people outside of the university. Personal research topics are organized alphabetically by the name of the researcher.

The Audio-Visual Material series, 1985-2003 (2 linear feet) contains primarily videocassette tapes, but also audiocassettes. Most of the material is from various years of the Ann Arbor Flower and Garden Show. Also included is a videocassette containing the episode of HGTV's Great American Gardens that featured the Matthaei Botanical Gardens.
